front matter Lectors.
Syderaiungamus, facito mihi Iuppiter adsit, Et tibi Mercurius noster dabit omnia faxo.
To the Reader.
Too soone and too late, this work is published: Too soone, in that it was in the Presse, before I had notice of it, by which meanes some faults may escape in the Printing. Too late, for that it was not published when the general voice of the people had seald it for good, and the newnesse of it made it much more desired, then at this time: For Plaies in this Citie are like wenches new falne to the trade, onelie desired of your neatest gallants, whiles the'are fresh: when they grow stale they must be vented by Termers and Cuntrie chapmen. I know not how this labor will please, Sure I am it past the censure of the Stage with a generall applause, now (whether vox populi be vox dei or no) that I leaue to be tried by the accute iudgement of the famous six wits of the Citie: Farewell.

Actorum Nomina. Weomen.
1 Glistler A Doctor of Physicke. Purge A Iealous Pothecarie. Dryfat A Marchant, a brother of the Family. Gerardine A Louer. Lypsalue A Gallant that only pursue Citty Lechery. Guggin A Gallant that only pursue Citty Lechery. Club A Prentice. Viall Seruant to Glister. Smelt and Periwincle. Pages to the Gallants. Mystrisse Glister. Mistrisse Purge An Elder in the Family. Maria Neece to Glister.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: If for opinion hath not blazed his fame,
Nor expectation filled the general round,
You deem his labours slight, you both confound
Your graver judgment and his merits.
Impartial hearing fits judicious spirits.
Nor let the fruit of many an hour fall,
By envies tooth, or base detractions gall.
Both which are tokens of such abject spirits,
Which wanting worth, themselves hate other merits:
Or else of such, which once made great by fame,
Repine at those which seek to attain the same.
From both we know all truer judgments free
To them our muse with blushing modesty
Patiently to her entreats their favour,
Which done, with judgment praise, or else - dislike the labour.

div2.stage:
Main text
ACTVS PRIMVS.
Actus Primus, scena prima.
Enter Doctor Glister, his wife, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Glister.
sp.p: Tricks and shows; protestations with men are like tears with women, forgot ere the cheek be dry: Gerardine is a gentleman, his Lands be in Statutes: He is not for thee nor thou for him, he is a Gallant, and young thoughts be most unconstant.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yet young vines yield most wine.

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: But old veins the best, believe not these great breeched gallants, they love for profit, not for affection, if he brings thee to a fools paradise, he will forsake thee.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Which fortune, God send my enemy: Love is a cold heat, a bitter sweet, a pleasure full of pain, a huge loss, and no gain, why shouldest thou love him only?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Words cannot force what destiny hath sealed,
Who can resist the influence of his stars,
Or give a reason why he loves, or hates
Since our affections are not ruled by will,
But will by our affections. It is blasphemy
Against Loves most sacred deity, to axe
Why we do love, since it is his only power
That sways all our affections, all things which be
Beasts, Birds, Men, Gods, pay him their fealty

sp.speaker: Glister.
sp.p:
Tut, Love is an idle fantasy, bred by desire, nursed by delight, An humour that begins his dominion in Leo the Lion, the sign of the hart, and ends in Aries the Ram, the sign of the head, His power is to stir the blood, pricks up the flesh, fills all the body with a libidinous humour, and is indeed the overture of all Ladies: which to prevent, I have banished Gerardine(your dearly beloved) my house, and as for you, since I
am your guardian by my brothers last will, I will sequester you from all other rooms in my house, save this gallery, and your upper Chamber till in discretion I shall find it convenient, to enlarge you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My body you may Circumscribe, confine
And keep in bounds: But my unlimited love
Extends itself beyond all Circumscription.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Believe me Maria, I have known the natures of divers of these gallants, If they possess the unlimited love of us women in never so ample manner without the society of the body, I know how soon their love evadeth. Young men's love is like Ivy, it must have somewhat to Cleave to, or it never prospers. Love is like fasting days, but the body is like flesh days, and it is our English gallants fashion, to prefer a morsel of flesh before all the fasting days in the whole year.

sp.speaker: Glister.
sp.l: The news with you Vial?

sp.speaker: Viall.
sp.p: If it like your Worship, Here is Club Master Purge the Apothecaries Prentice come to invite you, my Mistress and mistress Maria to Supper, and to see master Gerrardines Will sealed.

sp.speaker: Gli.
sp.p: Tell Club my wife and myself will be there: but Maria shall not come.

There must be your sweet hearts parting feast; now he perceives no access to my house; he will to sea, A good riddance, If he returns not: you forsooth are his heir; that is not much amiss: Yet there may be tricks, I will not be overreached, Come to your Chamber? where till my return you shall be in safe Custody.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: O Silly men! which seek to keep in awe
Women's affections, which can know no law.

div2.stage:
Scena. 2.
Enter Gerardine, Lipsalue, and Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Now by the horns of Cupids bow, which hath been the bane to many a tall Citizen, I think there be no finer fools under Heaven, than we men when we are lovers. How thou goest Crying up and down with thy arms a cross for a wife, Which hadst thou; she would cross both arms head and heart: Dost not yet know the old saying, A wife brings but two good days, That is her wedding day, and death day.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Believe him Gerardine? he speaks now gospel, a man may take more wife with one hand, than he is able to put away with ten G. A wife is such a Cross, that all married men would most gladly be rid of.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And yet such to cross that all bachelors would gladly be creeping: to profane not thus the sacred name of love?
sp.l: You Libertines, who never knew the joys,
Nor precious thoughts of two consenting hearts.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Didst ever see the true picture of a lover? I can give thee the Hieroglyphic. And this it is, A man standing naked a wench tickling him on the left side with a feather and pricking him under the right side with a needle. The allegory as I take, is this; That at the first we are so overjoyed with obtaining a wife, That we conceit no heaven like to the first nights lodging, And that is the signification of the left side, for wives always in the night, take the left side place, but sir now come to the needle on the right side, that is the day time wherein she commands, Then sir she has a certain thing called Tongue, ten times more sharp than a needle, and that at the least displeasure, A man must have shot quite through him.

sp.speaker: Guggin.
sp.p: Gramercies Lipsalue my neat Courtier, but sirrah Gerrardine be thyself sociable and free? Leave not thy native soil for a Giglat, A wench who in her wit is proud.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: In her smile deceitful.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: In her hate revengeable.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: And in nothing but her death acceptable, I will tell thee; there is no creature more desirous of an honest name and worse keeps it, than a woman, Dost hear, follow this song and if ever thou forsake thy Country for a wagtail, let me be whipped to death with ladies hairlaces.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Let us hear that worthy song Gentle master Lipsalue.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.p: Observe?
sp.l: Now if I list will I love no more
Nor longer wait upon a gill.
Since every place now yields a wench
If one will not another will;
And if what I have heard be true
Then young and old, and all will do:
How dost thou like this? man.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.l: No more no more,
This is the chamber which Confines my love,
This is the Abstract of the spacious world,
Within it holds a Gem, so rich so rare
That Art or nature never yet could set
A valued prise to her in valued worth.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Unvalued worth, ha ha ha! Why she is? but a woman,
And they are windy turning veins, love light as chaff which when
Our nourishing grains are winnowed from them,
Unconstantly they fly at the least wind of passion
A woman's eye, can turn itself with quick dexterity
And in each wanton glass can comprehend
Their sundry fancy suited to each fend
tut their loves are all compact of levity
even like themselves, Nil muliere lenius.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Tut man everyone knows their worth, when they are at a rack rent; In the term time, they bear as great a prise as wheat when transportations are. ---

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Peace let us draw near the window and listen if we may hear her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Debarred of liberty! O that this flesh
could like swift moving thoughts transfer itself,
From place to place, unseen and undissolved:
Then should no iron ribs, or Churlish flint
divide my love and me, Deer Gerardin
despite of Chance or Guardians Tyranny,
I would move within thy orb and thou in mine.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: She would move within thy orb, and thou in hers, blood she talk bawdy to herself: Gudgeon stand close;

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But in vain do I proclaim my grief,
when air and walls can yield me no relief.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: The walls are the more stony hearted then,

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Peace good Gudgeon gape not so loud.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come thou my best companion, thou art sensible
and canst my wrongs reiterate; Thou and I,
will make some mirth in spite of Tyranny:
The black browed night drawn in her pithy wayne
In starry spangled pride rides now over heaven
Now is the time when stealing minutes tell
The stole delight joyed by all faithful lovers
Now loving souls contrive both place and means,
for wished pastimes only I am pent
within the closure of this fatal wall
deprived of all my joys.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My dear Maria be Comforted in this?
the frame of heaven shall sooner cease to move,
bright Phaebus Steeds leave their diurnal race
and all that is forsake their natural being
Ere I forget thy love.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Who is that protests so fast?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thy ever vowed servant Gerardine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O By your vows it seems you would fain get up

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Aye and ride too.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I would most loved Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I knew it: he that to get up to a fair woman
will stick to vow and swear, may be accounted no man,
but tell me why hast thou chose this hour to visit me?
which nor the day nor night can claim but both
or neither, why in this twilight camest thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To avoid suspicious eyes, I come dear love
To take my last farewell, fitting this hour
which nor bright day will claim nor pitchy night
An hour sit to part conjoined souls,
Since that my native soil will not afford
My wished and best content, I will forsake it
And prove more strange to it than it to me.
In times swift course all things shall find event
Be it good or ill, and destinies do grant
That most preposterous courses often gain,
What labour and direct proceedings miss.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wilt thou forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let first blessed life forsake me, be constant
My absence may procure thy more enlarge
and then ---

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Desires conceit is quick, I apprehend thee
Be thou as loyal, as I constant prove,
And time shall knit our mutual know of love,
Wear this my loves true pledge: I need not wish
I know thou wilt return, or will I say
Thou mayst conceal thyself being returned
till I may make escape and visit thee.
I prithee love attempt not to ascend
my Chamber window by a lathered rope?
the entrance is too narrow: except this post
Which may with ease, yet that is dangerous:
I pre thee do it not I hear some call: Farewell
my constant love let after actions tell;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O perfection of women!
A plague of such perfection, How she woes, by negatives shows

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Thee? what to do? under colour of dissuasion

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She is truly virtuous.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Tut man outward appearance is no authentic instance of the inward desires, women have sharp falcons eyes, and can soar aloft, but keep them like Falcons from flesh and they soon stoop to a gaudy lure.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Why then Hugonot women are admirable Angels.

sp.speaker: Gugg.
sp.p: But Angels make them admirable devils.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: My loves chaste smile to all the world doth speak her spotless innocence.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Women's smiles are more of custom than of courtesy, women are creatures, their hearts and they are full of holes, apt to receive but not retain affection; Thou wilt tomorrow thou sayst be gone, if thou wilt know the worst of a Countries marry before thou goest, for if thou canst endure a cursed wife, never care what company thou comest in.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Come merry gallants, will you associate me to my Cousin Purges the Apothecaries, and take part of my parting feasts tonight.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: O his wife is of the family of Love, I will thither, perhaps I may prove of the Fraternity in time, we will thither that is flat.

div2.stage:
Exeunt omnes. Act.1. Sena.3.
Enter Mistress Purge Sola.

sp.p: What Club, Club, is Club within there.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mist. Purge.
sp.p: I pray what said Master Doctor Glister, will he come.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: He sent word he would, for he was but to carry a diet to one of his patients; what call you her, she that paints a day times, and looks fair and fresh, on the outside, but in the night time is filthier than the inside of Bocardo, and is indeed far more unsavoury that know her forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: Went he to her.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: He had a receipt for the Grincomes in his hand, and he said he would take that in his way.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: It is well, and what guest besides him and his wife will be here at supper.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
The first in my Account is Master Gerarine your cousin:
Master Doctor Glister and his wife: Master Drifat the Merchant, Master Lipsalue the Courtier, Master Gudgeon the gallant, and their pages. These I take will be your full number.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Then be like my room shall be stuffed with Courtiers and gallants tonight: of all men I love not these gallants, they will prate much but do little, they are people most uncertain: They use great words, but little sense: great Beards, but little wit: Great breeches but no money.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: That was the last thing they swore away.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Belike they cannot fetch it again with swearing, for if they could, there is not a page of theirs, but would be as rich as a monarch.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: There is nothing mistress that is sworn out of date, that returns; their first oath in times past was by the Mass: And that they have sworn quite away: Then came they to their Faith, as by my Faith it is so: That in a short time was sworn away too; For no man believes now more than he sees. Then they swore by their honesties, and that mistress you know is sworn quite away: After their honesties was gone, then came they to their Gentility, and swore, as they were Gentlemen: and their Gentility they swore away so fast, that they had almost sworn away all the Ancient Gentry out of the Land, which indeed are scarce missed: for that Yeomen and Farmers Sons, with the help of a few welshmen, have undertook to supply their places. That at the last they came to Silver; and their Oath was, by the Cross of this silver, and swore so fast upon that, that now they have scarce left them a Cross for to Swear by.

sp.speaker: Mist. Purge.
sp.p: And what do they swear by now their money is gone.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Why by (---) if God refuse them.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: And can they not as well say men refuse them, as God refuse them.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
No mistress, for men, especially Citizens and rich
men, have refused them their bonds and protestations already.

sp.speaker: Mistrisse Pur.
sp.p: It is well, see how supper goes forward, and that my shoes be very well blacked, against I go to the Family.

Now sweet Chick, where hast thou been, in troth law I am not well, I had thought to have spent the morning at the Family, but now I am resolved to take pills, and therefore I prey thee desire Doctor Glister that he would minister to me, in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mast. Pur.
sp.l: Thy will is known, and this for answer say,
It is fit that wise men should their wives obey,
sp.p: And now sweet duck know, I have been for my cousin Gerardines Will and have it, he has given thee a legacy, but the total is Marias.

div2.stage: Enter Master Glister, Master Dryfatt, and Mistress Glister.

sp.p: Master Doctor, your wife and master Dryfat are most welcome, now were my cousin Gerardine and Master Lipsalue here, our number were complete.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Is this frantic Will done, will master Gerardine to sea, let me tell you I am no whit sorry, let such as will be headstrong bite on the bridle.

sp.speaker: Ma. Purge.
sp.p: It is here master Doctor, all his worth is Marias and locked in a trunk, which by tomorrow Sun, shall be delivered to your custody.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Methinks it were a reasonable match to bestow your Niece on master Gerardine: He is a most hopeful gentleman, and his revenue such, that having your Nieces portion to clear it of all encumbrances, it will maintain them both in a very worthy degree.

sp.speaker: Doctor Glist.
sp.p:
Tut, you are master Dryfatt the Merchant, your skill is greater in Cony skins and Wool-packs, than in Gentlemen, his Lands be in Statutes, you Merchants were wont to be Merchant staplers, but now Gentlemen have gotten up the trade, for there is not one
gentleman amongst twenty but his land be engaged in twenty Statutes staple.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.l: Let every man his humour have, I do at none repine,
I never regard whose wench I kiss, nor who doth the like by mine:
The indiferent minds I hold still best, what ever does befall,
For she that will do with me and thee, will be a wench for all;
sp.p: and how goes the squares.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pur.
sp.p: Your stay gentleman does wrong to a great many of good stomachs, your suppers expect you.

sp.speaker: Guggin.
sp.p: And we our suppers.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And from what good exercise come you three.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: From a play, where we saw most excellent Sampson excel the whole world in gate carrying.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Was it performed by the youths.

sp.speaker: Lypsal.
sp.p: By youths: why I tell thee we saw Sampson, and I hope it is not for youths to play Sampson: Believe it we saw Sampson bear the Town gates on his neck, from the lower to the upper stage, with that life and admirable accord, that it shall never be equalled (unless the whole new livery of Porters set their shoulders)

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: Fie fie, it is pity young Gentlemen can bestow their time no better, This playing is not lawful, for I cannot find that either plays or players were allowed in the prime Church of Ephesus by the Elders.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aha, I think she tickled you there.

sp.speaker: Ma. Purge.
sp.p: Cousin Gerardine, shall the Will be read before supper?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Before supper I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, before supper, for when these women's bellies be full their bones will be soon at rest.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Well Master Doctor Pity the state of a poor gentleman it is in you to stay his journey, and make him and yourself happy in his choice.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Hold you content shall this Will be read?

sp.speaker: Ma. Purge.
sp.p: It shall, read you good Master Lipsalue.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Command silence then.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: In the name of God Amen. Know all men by these presence, that I Gerardine being strong of body, and perfect in sense.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: That is false, there is no lover in his perfect sense.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Peace Dryfat.

sp.speaker: Lypsal.
sp.p: Do give and grant to Maria Glister: Daughter of Iohn Glister, and Niece to Doctor Glister Physician, all my leases, lands, Chattels, goods and movables whatsoever: This is stark nought, you cannot give away your movables, for Mistress Doctor and Mistress Purge, claim both shares in your movables by reason of their legacies.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: That is true, for their legacies must go out of your movables.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Aye put it in all my movables, these following Legacies being paid.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Do so good Master Lypsalue.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: It is done.

sp.speaker: Mist. Purge.
sp.p: I pray read only the Legacies, for Supper stays.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Well, the Legacies, first I give to my Cousin Mistress Purge A fair large standing, what is this, O Cup; A fair large standing cup, with a close stool.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: It is not so, it is not so.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, a close cover it is, To mistress Doctor I give a fair Bodkin of gold, with two orient Pearls attending the same: All which are in my Trunk to be delivered to the keeping of Maria, In witness, etcetera. Is this your Will?

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: To it with your hand and seal.

sp.speaker: Mist. Purge.
sp.p: How is it Chick, I must have the standing Cup, and mistress Glister the bodkin.

sp.speaker: Mast. Purge.
sp.p: Right sweet Duck.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: I pray gentlemen put to your hands.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Come, your fists Gentlemen your fists.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Mistress Glister, I have found you always more flexible to understand the estate of a poor gentleman, than your husband was willing, therefore I have thought it a point of charity to reveal the wrongs you sustained by your husbands looseness. Let me tell you in private, that the Doctor cuckolds Purgo oftener than he visits one of his patients: what he spares from you, he spends lavishly on her: These Apothecaries are a kind of panders, look to it, if he keep Maria long close, it is for some lascivious end of his own.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: She is his Niece.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Tut, these Doctors have tricks, your niceness is such, that you can endure no polluted shows in your house, take heed lest he make you a Bawd before your time, look to it.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Come, our hands are testimonies to thy follies, shall us now to supper, we will have a health go round to thy voyage.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Aye and to all that forswear marriage, and can be content with other men's wives.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Of which consort you two are grounds, one touches the Base, and the other tickles the minikin.
sp.l: But to our cheer, come gentles let us away,
The Roastmeat is in consumption by our stay.

div2.stage:
ACTVS SECVNDVS.
Actus Secundus, scena prima. Enter Master Purge.

sp.p:
The gray eyed morning Braves me to my face, and calls me sluggard, it is time for Tradesmen to be in their
shops, for he that tends well his shop, and hath an alluring wife, with a graceful what ye lack, shall be sure to have good doings, and good doings is that, that crowns so many Citizens, with the horns of abundance. My wife (by ordinary course) should this morning have been at the Family, but now her soft Pillow hath given her counsel to keep her bed, Master Doctor should (indeed) minister to her: to whose pills she is so much accustomed, that now her body looks for them as duly, as the Moon shakes off the old, and borrows new horns. I smile to myself to hear our Knights and gallants say, how they gull us Citizens, when indeed we gull them, or rather, they gull themselves: Here they come (in Term time,) higher Chambers, and perhaps kiss our wives: Well: what lose I by that: Gods blessing on his heart I say still, that makes much of my wife, for they were very hard favoured, that none could find in his heart to love but ourselves: Drugs would be dog cheap but for my private well practiced doctor, and such customers. Tut, jealousy is a hell, and they that will thrive, must utter their wares as they can, and wink at small faults.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: The tedious night is past, and the jocund morn looks more lively and fresh, than an old gentlewoman's glazed face in a new periwig; By this time my humorous lover is at Grauesend, and I go with more joy to fetch his trunk, than ever the valiant Trojans did to draw in the Grecian Jade, his goods shall into the walls of my Troy, and be offered to a face more lively, than ever was that thrice ravished Helen, yet with such Caution, that no danger shall happen to me.

div2.stage: Lypsalue and Gudgeon at several doors, with their Pages, Shrimp and Periwinde.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master Lipsalue, welcome within ken, we two are so nearly linked, that if thou beest absent but one two hours, thy acquaintance grows almost mouldy in my memory.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: And then fly blown in mine how dost thou do.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: Fellow page, I think our acquaintance runs low too, but if it run not on the lees, let us set it a tilt, and give them some dregs to their mouldy fly blown complements.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: No rather let us pierce the Rundlets of our running heads and give them a neat cup of wagship, to put down their Courtship.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Courtship, Cartship: for the tongues of Complimenters run on wheels: but mark them they have not done yet.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: And i'faith how is it: methinks thou hast been a long vagrant.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The Rogation hath been long indeed: therefore we may salute as ceremoniously as Lawyers when they meet after a long vacation, who to renew the discontinued state Tale, they stretch it out with such length, that whilst they greet before, their Clients kiss them behind.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: If his nose were put in the remainder of that state Tale, he would say it were an unsavoury one.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: I wonder why many men gird so at the Law.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I will tell thee, because they themselves have neither Law nor conscience.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: But what news now? how stands the state of things at Brussels.

sp.speaker: Lip.
Gud.
sp.p: Well fare the City yet: there virtue rides a cock-horse cherished and kept warm in good sables, and Fox fur, and with the breath of his nostrils, drives pride and covetousness before him, like his own shadow: beggars have whipping cheer, bounty obliges men to it, gives money for Scrips and Scrolls, and liberality sealed with strong Arms and Heraldry, to out live mortality: love there will see the last man born, never give over while there is an Arrow in the Quiver.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Now we talk of love, I do know not far hence so good a subject for that humour, that if she would wear but the standing colour, and her things in fashion, our Ladies in the Court were but brown sugar candy, as gross as grocery to her.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: She is not so sweet as a apothecaries shop is she?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A plague on you, have you so good a sent? for my life he is my Rival.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: Her Name begins with mistress Purge does it not?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: True, the only comet of the City.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Aye, if she would let her Ruffs stream out a little wider; but I am sure she is ominous to me, she makes civil wars and insurrections in the state of my stomach: I had thought to have bound myself from love, but her purging comfits makes me loose bodied still.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: What has she ministered to thee then?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Faith some Lectuary or so.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Aye, I fear she takes too much of that Lectuary to stoop to love, it keeps her body soluble from sin, she is not troubled with carnal crudities, nor the binding of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Thou hast sounded her then belike.

sp.speaker: Lypsalue.
sp.p: Not I: I am too shallow to sound her, she is out of my Element, if I show passion, and discourse of love to her, she, tells me I am wide from the right scope, she says she has an other Object, and aims at a better Love than mine.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: O that is her husband.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: No, no, she speaks pure devotion, she is impenetrable, no gold, or Oratory, no virtue in herbs, nor no physic will make her love.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: More is the pity I say, that fair women should prove Saints, before Age had made them crooked: It is my luck to be crossed still, but I must not give over the chase.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Come hither boy while I think on it.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Faith friend Lipsalue I perceive you would fain play with my love, a pure creature it is, for whom I have sought every Angle of my brain: but either she scorns Courtiers (as most of them do, because, they are given to boast of their doings) or else she is exceeding straight laced: therefore to prevent this smell smock, I will to my friend Doctor Glister, (a man exquisite in the Art magic) who hath told me of many rare experiments available in this case: Farewell friend Lypsalue.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Adieu honest Gregorie, frequent my lodging, I have a Viol de Gambo and good Tobacco: Thou wilt do this feat boy?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Else knock my head and my pate together,

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Away then bid him bring his measure with him: Gerardine is travelled, and I must needs be cast into his mold: my flesh grows proud; and Maria is a sweet wench, etcetera. But yet I must not let fall my suite with mistress Purge, lest Cede vacanti my friend Gudgeon join issue: I will rather to my learned Doctor for a spell, for I have a fire in my liver, burns like Hell.

div2.stage:
Exit.
Enter Mistress Glister and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: I pray let us have no polluted feet nor Rheumatic chaps enter the house, I shall have my flower look more greasy shortly, than one of your Inn of Court dining Tables: and now to you good Niece I bend my speech, let me tell you plainly, you are a fool to be lovesick for any man, longer than he is in your company, are you so ignorant in the rules of Courtship, to think any one man to bear all the prick and praise? I tell thee, be he never so proper, there is an other to second him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Let rules of Courtship be authentic still,
To such as do pursue variety,
But unto those whose modest thoughts do tend,
To honoured Nuptials, and a regular life
As far from show of niceness, as from that
Of impure thoughts, all other objects seem
Respectless, of no proportion balanced with esteem
Of what their souls affect.

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: No marvel sure you should regard these men with such reverend opinion, there is few good faces, and fewer graces in any of them, if one among a multitude have a good pair of legs, he never leaves riding the ring, till he has quite marred the proportion: nay some (as I have heard) wanting lineaments to their liking, and Calf to support themselves, are fain to use Art, and supply themselves with quilted Calves, which oftentimes in Revelling fall about their Ankles, and for their behaviour, wit and discourse (except some few that are travelled) it is as imperfectious and silly, as your Scholars new come from the University, by this light I think we lose part of our happiness when we make these weathercocks our equals.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Disgrace not that for which our sect was made,
Society in nuptial beds above these joys
Which lovers taste, when their conjoined lips
Suck forth each others souls, the earth the Air,
Yea Gods themselves know none: Elisiums sweet
Aye all that bliss which Poets pens describe
Are only known, when soft and amorous folds,
Entwine the Corps of two united lovers,
Where what they wish, they have yet still desire,
And sweets are known without society.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here is Club forsooth and his fellow prentice have brought master Gerardines Trunk.

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: Let them come in if their feet be clean.

So then your best beloved is gone, fair weather after him; all thy passions go with him, recomfort thyself wench in a better choice, his love to thee would have been of no longer continuance
than the untrussing of his hose, then why shouldst thou pine for such a one.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: She is foolish sure, with what imperfect phrase, And shallow wit she answers me.

div2.stage: Enter Club and another with the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Mist. Gli.
sp.p: Honest Club welcome, is this master Gerardines Trunk? he is gone then?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Aye indeed mistress Glister, he is departed this transitory City, but his whole substance is here enclosed, which (by command) we here deliver to your custody, to the use of mistress Maria according to the tenure of the premises.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Place it here my honest Club, well done: and how does thy mistress was she at the Family today, --- spit not good Club, I cannot abide it.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Not today forsooth, she hath overcharged herself and her memory, she means to use a moderation, and take no more than she can make use of.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: And I pre thee Club what kind of creatures are these Familists, thou art conversant with them.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: What are they? With reverence be it spoken, they are the most accomplished Creatures under heaven, in them is all perfection.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: As how good Club?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Omitting their outward graces, I will show you only one instance which includes all other: they love their neighbours better than themselves.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Not than themselves Club.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Yes better than themselves, for they love them better than their husbands, and husband and wife are all one; therefore better than themselves.

sp.speaker: Mi. Glist.
sp.p: This is logic. But tell me doth she not endeavour to bring my Doctor of her side and Fraternity.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Let him resolve that himself for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: O: hast thou brought the Trunk honest Club, I commend thy honest care, here is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: I thank you master Doctor, you are free and liberal still, you will command me nothing back?

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: Nothing but commendations, farewell: your sweet heart Gerardine is by this time cold of his hope to enjoy thee: he is gone, and a more equal and able husband shall my care ere long provide thee: what clients have been here in my absence wife?

sp.speaker: Mi. Glist.
sp.p: Faith Mouse none that I know, more than an old woman that had lost her Cat, and came to you for a Spell in the recovery.

sp.speaker: Doctor Glist.
sp.p: I think egregious ignorance will go near to save this age, their blindness takes me for a conjurer: yesterday a Justice of peace salutes me, with proffer of a brace of Angels to help him to his foot-cloth, some three days before stolen, and was fain to use his man's cloak in stead of it.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here is a gentleman craves speech with you sir.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: Go in sweet wife, and give my Niece good counsel: His name.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: He will not tell it me.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: His countenance.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I can see nothing but his eyes; the rest of him is so rapt in cloak, that it suffers no view.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Admit him, what should he be for a man: what Master Lipsalue is it you? why thus obscured, what discontent overshadows you.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A discontent indeed Master Doctor, which to shake off, I must have you extend your Art to the utmost bounds: you physicians are as good as false doors behind hangings to Ladies necessary uses: you know the very hour in which they have neither will to deny, nor wit to mistrust: faith now by the way, when are women most apt.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: Shall I unbutton myself unto you; after the receipt of a purgation for then are their pores most open: but what creature of a Courtier is it, hath drawn your head into the woodcocks noose.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: A Courtier? nay by this flesh, I am clean fallen out with them, they have nothing proportionable.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: O I perceive then it is some City Star that attracts your aspect.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: He knows by his Art --- in plain terms a certain Apothecaries wife.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Upon my life master Purge, I smell you sir.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: You may smell a man after a purgation indeed: Sir, it is she: Now for that same hath bruited you to be a man expert in nigromancy, I would endeavour myself to you for ever, would you vouchsafe to let one of your Spirits bring Mistress Purge into some convenient place, where I might enjoy her: I have heard of the like, can you perform this.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: With much facility I assure you: but you must understand, that the apparition of a spirit is dreadful, and with all covetous, and with no small sum of gold hired to such feats.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Sir here is another gentleman muffled too, that desires present conference with you.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: Walk you into that room, I will bethink myself for your good, and instantly resolve you; let the gentleman come in: Lipsalue in love with my vessel of ease? come to me to help him to a morsel most affected by mine own palate? No more but so, I have shaped it, the conceit tickles me.
Sir, as a stranger I welcome you, what master Gudgeon have I caught you: I thought it was a gallant that walked muffled, Come, let me behold you at full, here are no Sergeants man.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master Doctor, this my obscure coming requires an action more obscure: and in brief this it is; Sir, you are held a man far seen in natures secrets, I know you can effect many things almost impossible; know then I love mistress Purge, and opportunity favours me not, nor indeed is she so tractable as I expected, if either by medicine, or your Art magical, you can work her to my will, I have a poor Gallants reward sir.

sp.speaker: Doct, Glist.
sp.p: That is just nothing. But how sir would you have me to procure you access to mistress Purge, you never knew a physician a bawd.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Why by conjuration (I tell you) wherein you are said to be as well practised, as in Physic; here is the best part of my present store to effect it.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.

sp.p: Who is within there, fetch me in all haste two good whips, I think you may have them not far hence; It shall be so, now tell me master Gudgeon does no man know of your love to mistress Purge.:

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Not a man by my Gentry.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Then sir know I will effect it; but understand withal, the apparition will be most horrid, if it appear in his proper form, and will so amaze and dull your senses, that your appetite will be lost and weak, though mistress Purge should attend it naked Now sir, could you name a friend with whom you are most conversant, in his likeness should the spirit appear.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Of all men living, my conversation is most frequent with Lipsalue the Courtier.

sp.speaker: Doct. Gli.
sp.p: It is enough: I will to my Spirit --- are these whips come there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ready here sir.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p:
So lie thou there; my noble gallants I will so firk you: Sir my Spirit agrees in Lipsalues shape; tomorrow betwixt the hours of four and five, shall mistress Purge be rapt with a whirlwind into Lypsalues chamber, that is the fittest place: for by the break of day Lipsalue shall be mounted, and forsake the City for three days, so my Spirit resolves me: Now sir, by my Art, at that very hour shall his chamber door fly open,
into which boldly enter in this sort accoutred: put me on a pure cleave shirt, leave off your doublet, (for Spirits endure nothing polluted) take me this whip in your hand, and being entered you shall see the Spirit in Lipsalues shape, in the self same form that you appear; speak these words here ready written, take three bold steps forward, then whip him soundly, who straight vanisheth and leaves mistress Purge to your will.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Aye but shall your Spirit come armed with a whip too?

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: He shall, but have no power to strike.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Is this infallible, have you seen the proof?

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Probatum upon my word, I have seen the experience, if it fail, say I am a fool, and no Magician.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master Doctor I would you had some suite at Court, by the faith of a Courtier, I would beg it for you: Fare you well Sir, I shall report of you, as I find your charm.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: And no otherwise sir; let me understand how you thrive: ha, ha, ha, now to my friend Lipsalue, I must possess him with the same circumstance, wherein I am assured to get perpetual laughter in their follies, and my revenge.

div2.stage:
Exit.
Enter Maria over the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O which way shall I turn, or shift, or go,
To lose one thought of care, no soothing hope
Gives intermission, or beguiles one hour
Of tedious Time, which never will have end,
Whilst love pursues, in vain my absent friend,
Thou continent of wealth, whose want of store
For that it could not peize thine qual Scale
Of Avarice givest matter to my moan,
O dross the level of insatiate Eyes
The Devils Engine, and the souls corrupter,
Thou playest the Attorney against the lawful force
Of true affection, dost interpose a Barr,
betwixt Hearts conjoined; Cursed be thy seed of strife,
Whose progress chokes the natural course of life.

div2.stage: Gerardine rising out of the Trunk, she seems fearful, and flies.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Stay sweet Maria, I bring thee ample joy
To check that sudden fear, let thy sweet heart
That constant seat of thy affection,
Repay that blood exhausted from thy veins;
Fear not sweet wench? I am no apparition,
But the firm substance of thy truest friend,
Knowest thou me now?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Gerardine my love?
What unheard of accident presents
Thy unexpected self, and gives my heart
Matter of joy, mixed with astonishment.
I thought thou hadst been cabined in thy ship,
Not Trunked within my cruel guardians house.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That cruelty gives fuel to desire,
For love suppressed fares like a raging fire
which burns all obstacles that stop his course,
And mount aloft; the Ocean in his source
May easier hide himself, and be confined,
Than Love can be obscured; For in the mind,
She holds her seat, and through that heavenly essence,
Is near, when far remote; her virtual presence,
Fills (like the Air) all places, gives delight,
Hope in despair and heart, against fell despite.
That worst of men thy cruel guardian may
Keep down a while, but cannot dissipate
what heaven hath joined, for fate and providence,
Gave me this Stratagem, to let him know,
That Love will creep, where it is restrained to go.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I apprehend the rest: O rare conceit,
I see thy travel happily was feigned
To win access, which with small ease thou hast gained:
This Trunk, which he so greedily supposes,
Contains thy substance (as it doth indeed)
Upon thy fair pretence, in lieu of love
Bequeathed to me, if death should stop the course,
This Trunk (I say) he hugs; sink thou or swim,
So he may feed his wolf, that root of Sin;
His Avarice but heaven (that mocks man's might
Gives this close means to insist upon our right.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ingenious Spirit, true Oracle of love,
Thou hast prevented me, this was my plot,
Whose end and scope I long to imitate,
With accents free, and uncontrolled with fear,
Does opportunity stand fair?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Not now,
Danger stands sentinel.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then I will retire,
We must be cautelous.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So so, and Time
Shall not oft turn his hour glass ere I will find,
Peace and occasion fitting to thy mind.

div2.stage:
ACTVS TERTIVS.
Actus Tertius scena prima.
Enter Gerardine and Maria.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The coast is clear, and Argus wakeful eyes
Securely sleep: time turns to us his front;
Come sweet Maria of the auspicious hours
Let us take advantage.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: With all my heart, I do embrace the motion with thyself:
Welcome sweet friend to liberty of Air,
Which now methinks doth prompt our breaths to move
Sweet accents of delight, the joys of love:
How dost thou brooke thy little ease, thy Trunk?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That Trunk confines this Chest, this Chest contains
The unbounded speculation of our love
Incomprehensible: Grief, joy, hope, and fears
(The affections of my mind) are like the spheres,
Which in their jarring motions do agree,
Through the influence of loves sweet harmony.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are not inferior bodies here on earth,
Produced and governed by those heavenly ones?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: They are.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They jar (you say) yet in that strife maintain
Perpetual league: why should their influence
In rational souls be checked by erring sense?
Or why should mutual love (confirmed by heaven)
Be infringed by men, methinks it is most uneven.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou arguest well Maria: and this withal
That Brutes, nor Animals do prove a thrall
To such servility: souls that are wards
To gold opinion, or the undue regards
Of broking men, wolves that in sheep-skin bands.
Pray on the hearts to join the unwilling hands,
Ruin fair Stocks, when generous houses die,
Or propagate their name with Bastardy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sterility and bareness ensue,
Such forced love: nor shall erroneous men
Pervert my settled thoughts, or turn mine eye
From thy fair object, which I will pursue,
Rich in thy love, proud of this interview.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will suck these accents, let our breaths engender
A generation of such pleasing sounds,
To interchange delights. O my blood is on fire,
Sweet let me give more scope to true desire.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What wouldst thou more than our minds firm contract?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tut words are wind: thought unreduced to Art,
Is but an Embryon in the truest sense.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am beleaguered I had need of sense,
You make me blush: play fair yet above board:

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here me exemplify loves Latin word
Together with thyself
As thus: hearts joined Amour: take A from thence,
Then more is the perfect moral sense,
Plural in manners, which in thee do shine
Saint-like, immortal, spotless and divine.
Take me away, over in beauties name,
Craves an eternal Trophy to thy fame.
Lastly take o, in re stands all my rest,
which I in Chaucer style do term a jest.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You break all modest bounds, away, away?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So when men come behind, do women say.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come come, I say

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Aye that is the word indeed,
Men that come bold before, are like to speed.

div2.stage: Enter Lipsalue and Shrimp his Page.

sp.p: But who comes here? monstrum horrendum, my nostrils have the rank sent of knavery, Maria let us remove ourselves to the window, and observe this piece of man's flesh.
Now mistress Maria ward yourself, if my strong hope fail not, I shall be with you to bring.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: To bring what sir? some more of your kind.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Faith boy that is mine aim.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I will be sworn sir, you have a good loose, you let fly at them a pace.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: I have shot fair and far off, but now I hope to hit the mark indeed.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: God save it.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: But where is the Sign?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Why there.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: That is a special thing to be observed.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I have heard talk of the Gemini, methinks that should be a Star favourable to your proceeding.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The Gemini, O I apprehend thee: that is because I am so like Gerardine, ha is it not so boy?

sp.speaker: Shr.
Lipsalue.
sp.p: Indefatigable boy, indefatigable.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Fatiguable (quoth you) you may call it leanable well enough, for I am sure it is able to make a man lean.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: It is my vocation boy, we must never be weary of well doing, love is as proper to a Courtier, as preciseness to a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Love (subbandy lust) a Punk in this place subintelligitur.

sp.speaker: Lypsalue.
sp.p: Boy I have spied my saint.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Then down on your knees.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Fly off, lest she take thee for my familiar: Save thee sweet Maria, Nay wonder not (for thou thyself art wonder,) To see this unexpected gratulation.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Whom do I see? O how my senses wander?
Am not I Hero: art not thou Leander ?

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Thou art in the right sweet wench more of that vain;

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Her passion overcomes her, it is the kindest soul:
O excellent devise; it works, it works boy.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: It does in deed sir, like the suds of an Alefat, or a washing Bole.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Joy not too much, extremes are perilous.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O weather beaten love: Cisley go make a fire?
o fetch my ladder of Ropes, Leander has come.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Mark how prettily in her rapture she harps upon Gerardines travel, let the ecstacy have end for I am Gerardine.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: The devil you are.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ha? let me see, my love so soon returned.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.l: I never travelled farther than thine eyes,
My bruited journey was a happy project,
To cast a mist before thy jealous guardian,
Who now suspectless, gives some hope to attain
My wished delight, before pursued in vain.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ask if he strained not hard for that same project.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Has not that project overracked thy brain.
And spent more wit than thou hast left behind.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.p: By this light she flouts him.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: No, wit is infinite I spent some brain;
Thy love did stretch my wit upon the Tenters

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then is it like to shrink in the wetting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It cottons well, it cannot choose but bear
A pretty nap; I tender thy capacity,
A comfortable Caudle cherish it:
But where is my favour that I bid thee wear
As pledge of love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now dost thou put him to it,
More Tenters for his wit, he is Nonplus quite

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: I wear it sweet Maria but on high days,
Preserve it from the tainting of the air,
What should I say: it is in my other hose,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How: in your other hose? he that I love
Shall wear my favour in those hose he has on.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Fiends and furies: block that I am.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: In your other hose? she talked of a ladder of Ropes; if she would let it down; for my life he would hang himself in it: In your other hose? why those hose are in Lavender, besides, they have never a Cod piece: but in deed there needs no Ivy where the wine is good. In your other hose?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I said you were too prodigal of wit.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.l: Expostulate no more, grant me access,
Or else I will travel to the wilderness.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Your only way, go travel till you tire,
Be rid, and let a gull discharge the hire.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Master, the Doctor the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Where? which way.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: This way, that way, some way I heard him coming.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O boy I am abused, gulled, disgraced, my credit is cracked.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: You know that is nothing for a new Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O I shall run beside myself.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: No sir, that is my office, I will run by your side.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: My brain is out of temper, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Take her council sir, get a cullis to your capacity, a restorative to your reason, and a warming pan to your wit: he comes he comes.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Follow close boy, let him not see us.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: What more flatterers about my carrion? more battery to my walls? shall I never be rid of these Petronel Flashes? As for my friend Gerardine, the wind of my rage has blown him to discover countries, and let the sea purge his love away and him together, I care not: young wenches now are all of the heigh: we that are guardians must respect more besides Titles, gold lace, person, or parts, we must have Lordships and manors, else where as well as in the man: wealth commands all, and wealth I will have, or else my minion shall lead Apes in hell. I must after this gallant too, I will know his rendezvous, and what company he keeps.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now must we be abrupt; retire sweet friend
To thy small ease; what more remains to do,
We will consummate at our next interview.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So shall I bear my prisonment with pleasure,
Look thou but big or cruel, foe will yield,
And give to Hymen the honour of the field.

div2.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Mistress Purge, and Club before her with a Link.

sp.speaker: Mist. Purge.
sp.p: Fie fie Club, go a other side the way, thou callowest me and my ruff, thou wilt make me an unclean member in the congregation,

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: If you be unclean mistress, you may pure yourself, you have my masters ware at your commandment, but what am I then, that does all the drudgery in your House.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Thou art born to it, why boy I can show thy Indentures thou givest no other milk: we know how to use all in their kind.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
You are my better in Bark and Rhine, but in pith and
substance I may compare with you: you are above me in flesh mistress, and there is your boast, but in my other part, we are all one before God.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: All one with me! dost thou swear too? why then up and ride.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Wither away mistress Purge?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur,
sp.p: To the Family master Dryfat to our exercise.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What by night?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: O Lord, Aye sir, with the candles out too, we fructify best in the dark, the glance of the Eye is a great matter, it leads us to other objects besides the right.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Indeed I think we perform those functions best, when we are not thrall to the fetters of the body.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: The fetters of the body, what call you them?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: The Organs of the body, as some term them.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Organs: fie, fie, they have a most abominable squeaking sound in mine ears, they edify not a whit I detest them: I hope my body has no Organs.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: To speak more familiarly Mistress Purge, they are the senses: the sight, hearing, smelling, taste, and feeling.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: Aye marry: (Marry said I Lord what a words that in my mouth) you speak now Master Dryfat: but yet let me tell you where you err too: this feeling I will prove to be neither Organ nor fetter, it is a thing (a sense did you call it?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aye, a sense.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: Why then a sense let it be (I say it is that we cannot be without: for (as I take it) it is a part belonging to understanding; understanding (you know) lifteth up the mind from earth; if the mind be lift up, you know the body goes with it: also it descends into the conscience, and there tickles us with our works and doings: so that we make singular use of feeling.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: And not of the rest?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Not at that time; therefore we hold it not amiss to put out the candles, for the soul sees best in the dark.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: You come to me now Mistress Purge.

sp.speaker: M. Pu.
sp.p: Nay I will come to you else Master Dryfat: these senses (as you term them) are of much efficacy in carnal mixtures, that is, when we crowd and thrust a man and a woman together.

div2.stage: Enter Purge and over hears them.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: What so close at it: I thought this was one end of your exercise. Byrlady I think there is small profit in this, I will wink no more for I am now tickled with a conceit that it is a scurvy thing to be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I commend this zeal in you Mistress Purge, I desire much to be of your society.

sp.speaker: M. Pu.
sp.p: Do you indeed, blessing on your heart: are you upright in your dealings?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Yes, I do love to stand to anything I do, though I lose by it, in truth I deal but too truly for this world: You shall hear how far I am entered in the right way already: First I live in Charity and give small Alms to such as be not of the right Sect. I take under twenty in the hundred, nor no forfeiture of Bonds unless the law tell my conscience I may do it, I set no pot on a sundays, but feed on cold meat dressed a Saturdays, I keep no holidays, nor fasts, but eat most flesh on Fridays of all days in the week: I do use to say inspired graces able to starve a wicked man with length, I have Aminadabs and Abrams to my godsons, and I chide them when they ask me blessing: and I do hate the red letter, more than I follow the written verity.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Here is Clergy.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: These are the Rudiments indeed Master Dryfat.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Nay I can tell you I am or will be of the right stamp.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: A pox on your Stamp.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: Then learn the word for your admittance, and you will be much made on by the Congregation.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aye the word good Mistress Purge.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: A Brother in the Family.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Enough I have my lesson.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: So have I mine, A Brother in the family, I must be a familist today, I will follow this gear while it is on foot i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: Then shore up your eyes, and lead the way to the goodliest people that ever turned up the white of the eye, give me my book Club, put out thy Link, and come behind us.
Who is there?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Two brothers and a Sister in the Family --- Let in.
Who is there?

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: A Familiar brother.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Here is no room for you nor your familiarity.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
How? no room for me nor my familiarity? why what is the difference between a familiar brother, and a brother in the Family? O I know: I made eclipses of in, in this place where it should have been expressed, so that the want of in, put me clean out; or let me see: may it not be some mystery drawn from Arithmetic? For my life these Familists love no subtraction, take nothing away, but put in and add as much as you will, and after addition follows multiplication of a most Pharafithipocriticall crew. Well for my part I like not this family, nor indeed some kind of private lecturing that women use: look to it, you that have such gadders to your wives: self-willed they are as children, and i'faith capable of not much more than they peevish by custom, naturally fools. I remember a pretty wooden sentence in a preamble to an exercise, where the Reader prayed: that men of his Coat might grow up like Cedars to make good wainscot in the house of sincerity, would not this wainscot phrase be writ in Brass, to publish him that spake it for an Animal: why, such wooden pellets out of earthen Trunks, do strike these females into admiration, hits them home, sometimes (perhaps) in at one ear, and out at other, and then they depart in opinion, wiser than their neighbours, fraught with matter, able to take down and mortify their husbands. Well I will home now, and bring the true word next time: I shall expect my wife anon red hot with zeal, and big with melting tears; and this night do I expect, (as her manner is) she will weep me a whole Chamber-pot full, Liquor Lapides? do I cast pills abroad? it is no matter what I
say, I talk like a Apothecary (as I am) I have only purged myself of a little choler and passion, and am now armed with a patient resolution, but how? to put my Horns in my Pocket? no:
sp.l: What wise men bear is not for me to scorn,
It is a honourable thing to wear the horn.

div2.stage:
Exit.
Enter Lipsalue with his whip.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Fortune, devils turd in thy teeth, I will turn no more on thy wheel, Art is above thy might: what though my project with Mistress Maria failed, more ways to the wood than one, there is variety in love. It is believed I am out of town, my door is open, the hour is at hand, all things squared by the Doctors rule, and now I look for the Spirit to bring me warm comfort, to cloth my nakedness, and that is Mistress Purge, the cordial of a Familist, and come quickly good Spirit, or else my teeth will chatter for thee.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: O the naked pastimes of love, the scourge of dullness, the purifier of uncleanness, and the hot house of humanity: I have taken physic of master Purge, any time this twelve months to purge my humour upon his wife, and I have ever found her so fugitive, from exercise to exercise, and from family to Family, that I could never yet open the close stool of my mind to her: so that I may well say with Ouid: Hei mihi quod nullus amor est medicabilis herbis: now am I driven to prove the violent virtue of conjuration, if it hit, and that I yerk my familist out of the Spirit, I will hang up my Scourge-stick for a Trophy, and imparadise my thoughts, though the Doctor go to the devil, it is no matter: ha let me see; Lipsalues door open! and himself out of town? excellent Doctor, soothsaying Doctor, oraculous Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
I have taken up this standing to see my Gallants play at Barriers with Scourge-sticks for the honour of my Punk: and in good time I see my brave Spirits shining in bright Armour
nakedly burning in the Hell fire of Lechery, and ready for the hot encounter: sound Trumpets, the Combatants are mounted.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: The apparition: Mistress Purge peers through him, I see her.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The spirit appears: but he might have come sooner: I am numbed with cold, a shivering ague hath taken away my Courage.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: They are afraid one of another, look how they tremble, the flesh and the devil strengthen them: ha,ha, ha

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Has he no cloven feet, what a laxative fever shakes me.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Will he not carry me with him to Hell? well I must venture: Clogmathos

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: My Cue: Clogmathathos.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: My Cue Garrazin.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Garragas.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Garrazinos.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Ton tetuphon.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Tes tetuphes.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: With a Whirly Twinos --- they lash one another.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, gog's wounds, Gog's blood, a pox, a plague, the Devil take you, truce, truce, I smart, I smart.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. O for one of the hoops of my Cornelius Tub: I must needs be gone, I shall burst myself with laughing else:
sp.l: Magic hath no such Rule, men cannot find,
Lust ever better handled in his kind.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: What are thou? with the name of Jove I conjure thee?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: With any name saving the whip, I will no more of that conjuration a plague on it.

sp.speaker: Gudg.
sp.p: Speak art not a Spirit, in the likeness of my friend Lipsalue, that should transform thyself to mistress Purge.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: How? a Spirit? I hope Spirits have no flesh and blood, and I am sure thou hast drawn blood out of my flesh with the spirit of thy whip.
Then shall we prove to be honest Gulls, and the Doctor an errant knave.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A plague upon him for a Glister. he has given our loves a suppository with a Recombentibus --- I will tell thee sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Tell not me, let me prevent thee, the wind shall not take the breath of our gross abuse, we feel the gullery: Therefore let us swear by our naked truths, and by the hilts of these our blades, our flesh-tamers, to be revenged upon that Paraperopandenticall Doctor, that pocky Doctor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Agreed, we will Cuckold him, that he shall not be able to put his head in at his doors, and make his precise puritanical, and peculiar Punk his Apothecaries drug there, a known Cockatrice to the world.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: If report catch this knavery, we have lost our reputations for ever,
sp.l: Wherefore let us be secret;
Ill tax we women of Credulity,
When men are gulled with such gross foppery.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Come let us in, and cover both our shames?
This Conjuration to the world is a novelty,
Gallants turned Spirits and whipped for Lechery.

div2.stage:
Act.3. Scen. 4.
Enter Maria and Gerardine out of the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Gerardine come forth Maria calls?
Those Ribs shall not enfold thy buxom Limbs
One minute longer the cincture of mine arms
Shall more securely keep thy soul from harms.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What heavenly breath of Phitonessaes power
(That raised the dead corpse of her friend to life)
Prevails no less on me, for even this urn
(The figure of my sadder Requiem )
Gives up my bones, my love, my life, and all
To her, that gives me freedom in my thrall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Be brief sweet friend, salute and part in one,
For niggard time now threats with imminent danger
Our late joyed scope. Thy earnest then of love
Ere Sol have compassed half the signs, I fear
Will show a blushing fault, but it was thy plot, thine aim,
To enforce consent in him that bars thy claim.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Love salves that fault, let time our guilt reveal,
I will never deny my Deed, my hand, and Seal.
The Elements shall lose their ancient force;
Water and earth suppress the fire and Air,
Nature in all use, a preposterous course,
Each kind forget his likeness to repair,
Before I will falsify my faith to thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The humorous bodies elemental kind,
Shall sooner lose the innated heat of love,
The Soul in natures bounds shall be confined,
Heavens course shall retrograde, and leave to move
Ere I surcease to cherish mutual fire,
With thoughts refined in flames of true desire.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: These words are odours in the sacred shrine
Of Loves best deity: the marriage God
Longs to perform these ceremonious rites,
Which terminate our hopes; till mine grow full
I will use that intercourse amongst my friends,
That erst I did: then in the hight of joy,
I will come to challenge interest in my boy.
Till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You will come upon your Cue

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Doubt not of that;

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Then twenty times adieu.

div2.stage:
ACTVS QVARTVS.
Actus Quartus,scena prima.
Enter Lypsalue and Gudgeon, Shrimp and Periwinkle.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Come Boys, our clothes boys, and what is the most currant news Periwinkle.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: Faith sir, Fortune hath favoured us with no news, but what the Peddler brought from Norfolke.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Is there nothing stirring at Court Shrimp?

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: Faith there is sir, but nothing new.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Good wag faith, thou smellest somewhat of a Courtier, though thy Mother was a Citizens wife, Off with that filthy great Band, nay quick, on with your robe of sanctity; nay suddenly man.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: And why must we shift ourselves into this demure habit, if impossible to be of the Family, and keep our own fashion.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Tut man the name of a gallant is more hateful to them, than the sight of a Corner Cap, hadst thou heard the protestations the wife of a bellows-mender made but yesternight, against Gallants, thou hadst for ever abjured Crimson breeches. She swore that all Gallants, were persons inferior to bellows-menders, for the trade of Bellows-making was very aerial and high, And what were men and women but bellows, for they take wind in at one place, and do evaporate at another; evaporate was her very phrase.

sp.speaker: Guggin.
sp.p: Methinks her phrase flew with somewhat too strong a vapour.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Nay she proves farther, that all men receive their being chiefly from bellows, without which the fire burns not, without fire the pot seethes not, the pot not seething, powdered Beef is not to be eaten, of which she then averred our nation was a great devourer, and without which they could neither fight for their Country abroad, nor get children at home: For said she, powdered beef is a great joiner of nerves together.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: What answer madest thou?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Marry, that I thought a Bawd was a greater joiner of nerves together, than powdered beef, with that she protested, that a Bawd was an instrument of the Devil, and as she had proved that bellows-makers were of Gods trade, so Bawds were of the devils trade: For, (and thereupon she blew her Nose) the devil and Bawds did both live by the sins of the people.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: No more, mistress Purge is at hand.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p:
Vanish boys, away, make haste, before Jove she will be
with us ere we can be provided for her.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Advance your Link Club? At what time wert thou bound Club? At Guttyde; Hollantide, or Candletide?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: I was bound indeed about Midsummer.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p: And when hath thy prenticeship end, At Mychaeltyde next?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: So I take it.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: They say Club you fall very heavy on such you love not, you never learnt that of me.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Indeed mistress I must confess, my falling is rustic gross, and butcher-like, marry yours is a pretty foolish light Courttake falling: Yet believe me my master smells somewhat too gross of the Purgation, he wants tutoring.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: And why I pray?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: My master being set last night in his shop, comes master Doctor Glister (as his manner is) squirting in suddenly, and after some conference, tells my master that by his own knowledge you were young with Child, to which my master replied, why master Doctor, will you put me to more Charges yet?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Thou art a fool, In that my husband spake as wisely as if the master of his company had spoke, he knows Doctors have receipts for women, which makes them most apt to conceive, and he promising he had ministered the same lately to me, thereupon spake it, Lead on with your link?

sp.speaker: Lipsa.
sp.p: Art ready?

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Ready.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.p: Then speak pitifully, look scurvily, and dissemble cunningly, and we shall quickly prove two of the fraternity Benediction and Sanctity; love and Charity: fall on Mistress Purge, Sister of the family.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: And what I pray be you two?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Two newly converted from the rags of Christianity; to become good members in the house of the family.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Who I pray converted you?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Dryfat the merchant.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pur.
sp.p:
And from what sins hath he converted you?
From two very notorious Crimes, The first was from eating fish on fridays, and the second from speaking reverently of the Clergy: but he resolved us, your talent in edifying young men went far beyond his.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pur.
sp.p: A talent I have therein, I must confess, nor am I very nice at fit times to show it; for your better instructions therefore, you must never hereafter frequent taverns nor Taphouses, no Masks nor Mummeries, no pastimes nor Playhouses.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Must we have no recreation?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Yes, on the days which profane lips call Holidays, you may take your Spaniel and spend some hours at the Ducking pond.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: What are we bound unto, during the time we remain in the Family.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: During the light of the Candle, you are to be very attentive, which being extinguished, how to behave yourselves, I will deliver in private whisper.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pur.
sp.p: It is now come to a whisper, what young Familists be these? i'faith I will make one, I will trip you wife, I sent your footing wife.
sp.l: For Gallus writes, Paraselsus can tell,
Apothecaries have brains, and Noses eke to smell.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: We shall with much diligence observe it.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pur.
sp.p: I fear I shall have small cause to thank that diligence, but do your worst, He that hath read five herbals in one year, can find a trick which shall prevent this gear, they are going, follow Purge, close, close and softly, like a Horse-keeper in a Ladies matted Chamber at midnight.

div2.stage: Exeunt Gudgeon, Lipsalue, and Mistress Purge.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Brethren and a Sister in the Family.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Enter in peace.

sp.speaker: Ma. Purge.
sp.p: Brethren and a sister, that is the word, How beastly was I mistaken last day, I should have said a Brother in the Family --- And I said a Familiar brother, for which I and my family were thrust out of doors: but as Titus Silus of Holborn bridge most learnedly was wont to say, qd ---

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Ma. Pu.
sp.p: A brother in the family.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Enter, and welcome.

sp.l: Thou sacred Deity, love:
Thou power predominate, more to be admired,
Than able to be expressed, whose Orb includes
All terrene joys which are, all States which be,
Pay to thy sacred Throne, as tribute fee
Their thoughts and lives like Jove's so must thy acts
Endure no question, why, thy hidden facts,
The Gods themselves obey, Heaven Synod holds,
No Gods, but what thy awful power controlls,
The Delphian Archer proud with Pythons spoil
At Cupids hand was forced to take the foil:
Not Mars his warlike Adamantine Targe,
Could free his warlike breast at Cupids charge;
And Jove whose frown all mortal lives bereaves
This marble throne and Ivory Sceptre leaves:
And in the likeness of a Bull was seen,
As forced by him to bear the Tyrian Queen:
Through Neptune's watery kingdom, if these submit
My Metamorphosis is not held unfit:
sp.p: And see in most wished occasion Drifat the Merchant presents himself. Sir, in the best of hours met, my thoughts had marked you out for a man most apt, to do them the fairest of offices.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: What? art thou a welsh Carrier, or a Northern Landlord, thou art so saucy.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Is it possible sir, my disguise should so much fool your knowledge? how, a Northern Landlord? can you think I get my living by a bell and a Clackdish?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: By a bell and a Clackdish, how is that?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why by begging sir, know you me now?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Master. Gerardine, disguised and a shore, nay then I smell a Rat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Master Dryfat, shall I repose some trust in you, will you lay by a while your Cities precise humour, will you not deceive me?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: If I deceive your trust, the general plague seize me, that is, may I die a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I say thou shall die a true Citizen, if thou conceal it: And thus in brief, It stands with thy knowledge how seriously I have (and do still affect Maria: Now sir, I have so wrought it, that if thou couldst procure me a fellow, that could serve in stead of a Crier, I myself would play Placket the Paritor, and summon Doctor Glister and Maria to appear at thy house, and as he plays the paritor, so wouldst thou but assume the shape of a proctor, I should have the wench, thou the credit, and the whole City occasion of discourse this nine days.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: How is this, how is this! I should procure a fellow to play the Paritor, and I myself should play the proctor: but upon what occasion should they be summoned?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Upon an accusation, that Doctor Glister should get Maria his Niece with child, and have Bastards in the Country which I have a trick to make probable.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: And now I recall it to memory, I heard somewhat to that effect last night, in master Beardbush the Barbers shop, but how will this sort, who shall accuse him?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Refer that to me, I say, be that my care, all shall end in merriment, and no disgrace touch either of their reputations.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Then take both word and hand, it is done, Club (mistress purges prentice) shall be the Summoner.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O my most precious Dryfat, may none of thy daughters prove vessels with foul bungholes, or none of thy Sons hogsheads, but all true and honourable Drifats like thyself.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Well Master Gerardine, I hope to see you a Familist before I die.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That is most likely, for I hold most of their principles already: I never rail nor calumniate any man, but in love and charity; I never cousin any man for any ill will I bear him, but in love and charity to myself: I never make my neighbour a Cuckold for any hate or malice I bear him, but in love and charity to his wife.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: And may those principles fructify in your weak members: I will be gone, and with most quick dexterity provide you a Crier: Tomorrow at my house (said you) they should appear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Be that the time, most honoured Dryfat, but be this known to none, most loved sir, save Club, or to some other whom your judgment shall select, as a fit person for our project.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Thus enough time out of sight.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Maria, thou art mine earths affection and natures glory, woman of what an excellency, if her thoughts and acts were squared and leveled with the first celsitude of her creation:
sp.l: To enjoy a creature, whose dishevelled locks,
Like gems against the repercussive Sun,
Gives light and splendour. whose star-like eyes
Attract more gazer loves to see them move
Than the Tartarians God, when first Egeons Hill
Amounts in triumph, a skin more pure and soft,
than is the silkworm bed, to the more white
Than new fallen Snow, or shining Ivory,
Is happiness sought by the Gods themselves,
Celestial Venus born without a mother,
Be thou propitious, thee and I implore
Not vulgar Venus, Heavens scorn and Mars his whore.

div2.stage:
Exit.
Enter Mistress Glister and Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Good Aunt quiet yourself, ground not upon dreams, you know they are ever contrary.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p:
Minion, minion, coin no excuses; I grant dreams are deceitful, but a true judgment grounded upon knowledge never fails: what? have not I observed the rising and
