falling of the blood, the coming and going of the countenance, your qualms, your unlacings, your longings, most evident tokens, besides a more certain sign than all these too, you know it, I need not speak it; nay I am as skilful in that point as my husband: I can tell you Aristotle speaks English enough to tell me these secrets: Body of me, so narrowly looked too, and yet fly out? well, I see maids will have it, in spite of Laws or locks that restrain them, they will open, do men what they can.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I see my fault appears, simplicity
Hath no evasion: it is bootless to deny,
Where guilty blood, cited by touch of shame,
Runs through my veins, and leaves my conscience stain,
Even in my face for bear I do beseech you,
To publish my defame, what I have done,
You shall not answer, I must bear mine own.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Bear your own? Aye marry there it goes, what must you bear?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: My sins forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Your sins forsooth: confess to me, and go not about the bush, you have been doing that is flat, you have caught a clap, that is round, and answer me roundly to the point, or else I will square. Come whose act is it? I cannot devise unless it be my husbands, for none else had access to thee; I am sure time has turned his bald side to thee, and I do but wonder how thou tookest opportunity: speak tell me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now good Aunt press me not, let time reveal
What you suspect, for never shall my tongue
Confess an Act that tends unto my wrong.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Will you not bolt, I must have it out on you, and will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: By your leave mistress.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Passion of my heart, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No Ghost forsooth, though I appear in white.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: No, but a saucy knave I perceive by your manners.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
None of that Livery neither: I am of the bearing trade forsooth, you may see by my Smock --- frock I would say: I am (if it please you) of the spick and span new set up Company of Porters,
Here is my Breast plate, and besides our own Arms we have the arms of the City to help us in our burthens, Ecce siguum: here is the Cross, and the sword of Justice in good Pewter, I can tell you which goes as currant with us as better metal.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: What is your name sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nicholas Nebulo there is but a straws breadth between that and the Arms, it is in the back side of the Cross here, and well known in the City for an ancient name, and an honest if it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are none of the 12 are you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No forsooth but one of the 24.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Orders of knaves, I thought so, sirrah you are a Rascal to come thus bluntly into my house with your dirty Startups, get you without doors like a filthy fellow as you are, a place more fit for you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O good words mistress; I may be warden of my company for aught you know and for my bluntness we have a clause in our Charter to warrant that for as we bear, so likewise we may be born with, and have free egress and regress where our business lies.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: And what is your business here?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have a letter if it please you to master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That I cannot show your Worship, but I had it of Curtal the Carrier whose lawful deputy I am.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Leave your scraping sirrah: fie how rank the knave smells of grease and Taps droppings.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Coughs and spits.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: What are you Rheumatic too with a vengeance?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes indeed mistress, though I be but a poor man, I have a spice of the gentleman in me, Master Doctor could smell it quickly, by cause he is a gentleman himself; I must to the diet and that is Tobacco at the Alehouse, I use no other physic for it.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Did ever such a peasant defile my floor, or breathe so near me: i'faith sirrah you would be burned for your Roguery if you were well served.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am burned well enough already Mistress, look here else; sir-reverence in your worship, master Doctors lips are not made of better stuff.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: What an impudent Rogue is this: sirrah be gone I say, I would be rid of you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Be rid of me? I shall gallop then: you mistake me forsooth I am a foot-post, I do not use to ride.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gl.
sp.p: I think the Rascal be humorous or drunk: well I will read the letter and send him packing, or else he will spew or do worse before me: fie on him, I think he will infect me with some filthy disease.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Or else I loose mine aim.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: What is here Your poor nurse Thomasine Sweedlesse for my life now shall I find out my husbands knavery, I have so long suspected.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She begins to nibble, it will take i'faith --- mistress
I see some discontentment in your looks,
Care ill befits so delicate a spirit.
Be frolic wench for he that is so near thee
has been much nearer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That Accent sounds sweet music, it is my love.
That tongue breaths life into my liveless spirits
Gerardine! O rapture, why thus disguised!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No more, be mute; thus must I vary forms
To bring our Cares to end her Jealousy,
Ensues this Drift, which if it take true scope,
Loves joy comes next be fearless in that hope:

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: It is so: Rats bane: I hate, it rack is on it torments me here it is, --- Woe worth the time that ever I gave suck to a Child that came in at the window god knows how villainous Lecher; Yet if you did but see, how like the little red headed knave is to his Father damnable Doctor: A Bastard in the Country, and an other towards here I am out of doubt, this is his work. You are an Arrant Strumpet, Incest, fornication, abomination in my own house; intolerable; O for long nails o scratch out his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Or the breeches to fight with him.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Out of my sight quean, thou shalt to Bridewell --- O, I shall be mad with rage.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then you shall go to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Hence you Slave.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I must have a penny, you must pay me for my pains.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: The Devil pay thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O that is the Doctor, but he wants his horns.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: But I will furnish him ere long if I live.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It works as I would wish, farewell Maria,
This storm once past, fair weather ever after.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: Was ever woman so moved? but you shall be talked withal, and for mine old fornicator, he shall have it as hot as coals i'faith: here is stuff indeed! Come minx come, there is Law for you both, have I found your knavery: if I wink at this, let me be stone blind, or stoned to death, bear this and bear all.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Our hopes are crossed, sure there is some providence
Which countermands libidinous appetites,
For what we most intend, is counterchecked
By strange and unexpected accidents:
For by disguise procuring full access,
Nay ready to have feared the expected prize
The candle out, steps betwixt my hopes and me
Some pleasant Groin, possessed and full enjoyed
That sweet, for which our vigilant eyes have watched
And in one moment frustrates all our hopes.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: Upon my life we are bewitched, the greasy Rascal, that first seized Mistress Purge (by the last reflection of the light) appeared to my sight not much unlike her husband.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: The Courts gall, the Cities plague, and Europaes Sea form be his perpetual Crest, what ever he was. To loose Mistress Purge for lack of dexterity, is a disgrace insalvable. The like opportunity will never present itself.

sp.speaker: Gudg.
sp.p: It was an egregious grief, I must confess to see a knave slip betwixt us both, and take occasion by the foretop, but since these projects have had so star cross events, let us lay some plot how to revenge our late disgrace on the Doctor, by making him Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Agreed, but what melancholy sir with a cross stick arms now comes from the Family?

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Purge the apothecary, I prithee let us step aside and hear the issue of this discontent.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: O the misery of married men's estate!

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: He begins very pitifully.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O women what are many of you?

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Why disease to bachelors, and plagues to married men.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O marriage, the rage of all our miseries, my wife is a dissembling strumpet.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: So is many a man's besides yours, and what of that?

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: I would have a law that all such which pray little should instantly be married, for then would they pray continually if it were but to be rid of their wives.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: This is a charitable request and surely would pass the lower House.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Surely if affliction can bring a man to heaven I cannot see how any married man can be damned, I have made myself a plain Cuckold.
A pile on ye, want you? had you not been so manable, here are some would have saved you that labour.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p:
What shall I do in this extremity, had I but witness of the fact, I would make her answer it before authority, This is my wedding Ringe; It is it I know it by the posy This I took from her finger
in the dark, and she was therewith very well pleased, were not this trow, a sufficient testimony? She knows not that it was myself got so near her, I will take council; well, little know Bachelors the miseries they undergo, when they prostrate themselves to women.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O most true Master Purge, little knows a man what Elements he is to pass, when he puts his head under a woman's girdle: your passion Master Purge is over heard, and (plain tale to tell) we were eye witnesses of your wives treachery, and if need be will be ready to depose as much.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: What master Lipsalue and master Gudgeon are you disguised testimonies, nay then Revenge look big?
sp.l: Elf and Fairy
Help to revenge the wronged Apothecary?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Why now he speaks like himself, get me a Paritor for her straight?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Conceal the Ring, my little Purge, let not thy wife know thou hast it, until she comes to her trial.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Your advices are very pithy, therefore in private let me disclose my intent.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Off boys, Shrimp what dost thou think of thy Master, is a not a rare gull?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I think he will swallow, and pocket more disgraces than large cozenest Lawyer Fees in a Michaelmas Term. Thy master my honest Periwinkle comes not much short of a fool too, but that he is a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: Draw somewhat near, and overhear their conference?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: This shape of the Crier, must Club tomorrow assume: Are you fitted for Popin the Proctor?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Excellent! and have spent some study in the mystical cases of Venery: I can describe how often a man may lie with another man's wife, before he come to the white sheet.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How long is that?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Why till he be taken tardy. How long all women kind may by the statute profess and swear they are maids.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And how long is that?

sp.speaker: Dryfa.
sp.p: Why till their bellies be so big that it cannot be no longer concealed, but come forward towards Clysters.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: It must be so: let the summoner tickle her, you shall bring in these allegations and let us alone to swear them; who is this Master Dryfat? Opportunely met sir, and whither so fast? The news, the news?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen, I think to relate for news what I hear of Doctor Glister would come stale to your hearings.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O the getting of his niece with child, tut that is apparently known to all the company, but in the name of Jupiter what art thou? or from whence camest thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why sir? I come from compassing the corners of the Land.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Of what trade in the name of Pluto?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Of the devils trade, for I live as he does, by the sins of the people, In brief sir, I am Placket the Paritor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
Gerard.
sp.p: Sir, according to the old Ballad; my quorum nomina ready have I, with my pen and inkhorn hanging by: her name sir, her name?

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Is it no more but so?

sp.speaker: Purg.
sp.p: I have most right to her name, her name master Placket is my wife, Mistress Purge Sir: To what place dost thou belong?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: To the Commissioners, which sit tomorrow at master Dryfats upon the crimes of Doctor Glister and others.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p:
Sits there a commission Dryfat? Now for the love of
lechery, let us have mistress purge summoned, thither?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She makes my Quorum nomina reasonable full my grant Sir and she shall appear there upon a crime of concupiscence, Is not that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Yes my honest paritor, here is thy Fee.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: And see how happily it succeeds, mistress Purge is new come from the Family, let us step aside whilst Placket the paritor, gives her a Summons?

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: Content. To her Placket But see for the bribery of twelve pence you strike her not out of your Quorum nomina.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Fear not sir.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Forward apace Club.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Your name I take to be mistress Purge fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: M. Pu.
sp.p: I am mistress Purge, Purges wife the apothecary: what of that?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Now you shall see him tickle her with a Quorum nomina

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I cite you by virtue of my Quorum nomina to make your personal appearance by eight of the clock in the morrow morning, before certain commissioners at master Dryfats house to answer to an accusation of a crime of concupiscence?

sp.speaker: M. Pur.
sp.p: To answer a crime of concupiscence, what is that&H62; I pray?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Why it is to answer a venereal Crime, for having carnal copulation with others besides your husband.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pu.
sp.p: What are you I pray?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: By name Placket, By trade a paritor?

sp.speaker: Mis. Pu.
sp.p: And must I answer say you, to a venereal Crime? I tell thee placket the paritor, I am able to answer thee, or any man else in any venereal crime they will put me to: And so tell your Commissioners?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: If you fail your appearance, the penalty must fall heavy.

sp.speaker: Mi. pu.
sp.p: If it fall never so heavy, I am able to bear it and so set forward Club.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.p: Excellent i'faith after your wife Purge: read Placket thy quorum nomina my noble groat monger.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Silence, the first that marcheth in this fair rank is, Thumb the felt-maker, for getting his maid with child and sending his prentice to Bridewell for the fact, whip the Beadle, for letting a punk escape for a nights lodging, and bribe often groats, Bat the bellman, for lying with a wench in a Tailors stall at midnight when he should be performing his office.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: And Tipple the Tapster for deflowering a virgin in his seller. Doctor Glister, his wife, Maria: mistress Purge These be the complete number.

sp.speaker: Lipsa.
sp.p: Now dissolve and each to his occasion, till tomorrow morning.

div2.stage:
ACTVS QVINTVS.
Actus quintus Scena Prima.
Doctor Glister and Mistress Glister.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gl.
sp.p: This was your colour to keep her close, but what Cloak have you for hers and your own shame? What your own niece, your brothers daughter besides your bastard in the country?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Wife range not too far I would advise you? Come home in time? vex me not beyond sufferance: The two edged sword of thy tongue, hath drawn blood of my? patience, I say thou art all this while in an error.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p:
No, thou hast been all this while in an Urinal, thou hast gone out of thy compass in women's waters, You are a conjurer (forsooth) and can rouse your Spirits into Circles, a you old Fornicator that ever I saw that read beard of thine; now could I rail against thy complexion, I think in my conscience the Traces and Caparison of Venus coach, are made of red hairs
which may be a true Emblem, that no flaxen stuff, or tanned white leather draws love like them; I think thou manuredest thy Chin with the droppings of Eggs and Muscadine, before it bristled: a shame take thee and thy Lodestone: but it is no matter, Master Placket the Paritor has cited you, and you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O the raging jealousy of a woman! do you hear wife I will show myself a man of sense, and answer you with silence, or like a man of wisdom, speak in brief: I say you are a scold, and beware the Cucking stool?

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: I say you are a nynnyhammer, and beware the Cuckoo; for as sure as I have ware, I will traffic with the next Merchant venturer, and in good time here comes gallants of the right trade.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: All alone mistress Glister? meditating who shall be your next child's Father.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Indeed methinks that should be one end of her thought if it be but to cry quittance with her husband, of whose abuse the Town rings.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Flax and fire, flax and fire, here are fellows come in the nick, to light their matches at my tinder.

sp.speaker: Lipsalue.
sp.p: He tells you true mistress Glister, the Doctor hath made you ordinary in our Ordinaries, Satyrs whet their tooths, and steep rods in piss, Epigrams lie in Poetries pickle and we shall have rhyme out of all reason against you.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: Ere long he will take up his station at a Stationers, where we shall see him do penance in a Sheet at least.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: O I am nettled, my patience is so provoked, that I must doff my modesty: what shall I do? if ye be honest gentlemen, counsel me in my revenge, teach me what to do, make my Case your own.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Why you are in the common road of revenge, take which hand you will, you cannot go out of your way; it is as soon taken, as Time by his forepart.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Faith since he has struck with the sword, strike you with the Scabbard: in plain terms Cuckold him: you may as easily do it, as lie down on your bed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: This gear cottons i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: I apprehend you gentlemen: Lord how much better are two heads than one, to make one large head?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: You say true mistress Glister, there is help required in grafting, and how happily we come to tender our service: let our pretence be to take physic of the Doctor: and that he may with as much ease minister to us, as we to you, we will take a lodging in his house.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: How say you to this, is the colour good? dost like you?

sp.speaker: Mist. Glist.
sp.p: Passing well: the colour is so good, that you shall wear my favour out of the same piece.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Excellent, excellent, now shall we be revenged for the whipping; mistress Glister let me be your first man?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Nay soft sir: I plied her as soon as you.

sp.speaker: Doct. spoke by
sp.p: I should have an oar in her boat too by right?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: How ill advised were you to marry one with a red beard?

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: O master Lipsalue, I am not the first that has fallen under that ensign: there is no complexion more attractive in this time for women, than gold and red beards: such men are all liver.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Aye, but small heart, and less honesty.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Yes, they are honest too (in some kind) for they will beg before they will steal.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: That is true, for, for one that holds up his hand at the Sessions, you shall have ten come into the bawdy Court.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Was ever Beard so backbitten: this were enough to make redbeards turn medley:and dash them clean out of countenance: but I hope like mine they fear no colours: if you were ten Courtiers I will front you: I must give you physic with a pox: well, if I pepper ye not, call me Doctor Doddipoll: Master Lipsalue and master Gudgeon you are heartily welcome, I am very glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O master Doctor, your salutation is very suspicious?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why master Lipsalue?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: It can scarce be hearty, for physicians are rather glad to see men ill, than well.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Not so sir, you must distinguish of men: though this I know, virtue is not the end of all science, which commonly keeps the professor poor, some study quaestuary and gainful Arts, and everyone would thrive in his calling, but i'faith gentlemen, what wind drives you hither?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: The wind Collect master Doctor, or some such disease

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But not the Stone Collect?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O no sir, we have no obstructions in those parts, we are loose enough there.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you were troubled with that, my wife can tell you of an excellent remedy.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: We need it not, we need it not: but indeed master Doctor, for some private infirmities (which our waters shall make known to you) we desire to take some physic of you for a few days, and to that end we would take a lodging in your house during the time?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Shall we entreat your favour?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No entreaty gentlemen, you shall command me to search the very profundity of my skill for you. Have them in wife, and show them their lodging? I will think upon an other receipt, and follow you immediately.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: And i'faith we shall requite your pains to the full.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
To the fool you mean: I know you have the horn of plenty for me, which you would derive unto me, from the liberality of your bodies, not your minds; here are Lords, that having learned the O.P.Q. of Courtship, travel up and down among Citizens wives to show their learning, and bringing up: as if the City were not already a good proficient in the Court Hornbook: yes I warrant they have heads as capable as other men; Aye and some of them can wisely say with
the philosopher, that in knowing all they know nothing. Well, because I am of the Livery, and pay Scot and Lot amongst you, do but observe how I will fetch over my gallants for your sakes; they say I am of the right hair, and indeed they may stand to it, and hold the position good; saving with my wife: soft, are they not at pro and contra already? I know they are hot spurs, and I must have an eye to the maine. They have been whipped already for lechery, and yet the pride of the flesh pricks them; well I must in, I have given them such a Pill shall take them down, for lust must have his fill.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: Now natures pencil, and the hand of time,
Gives life and limb, to generations Act;
My shame and guilt in wordless notes appear
The argument of scorn, O now I stand
The Theme and comment to each liberal tongue,
Whilst hope breeds comfort, and fear threats my wrong.
O Gerardine how oft thy lively figure
(Deadly impressed in my yielding temper)
Assures me thou art mine: how fancy paints
Thy true proportion in my troubled sleep,
Because sole subject of my daily thoughts;
O if thy vows prove feigned, and thou unjust,
I say and swear, in men there is no trust.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thus have I past the Round and Court of Guard,
Without the word: either conceit is strong,
Or else the Body where true love is confined,
Walks as a Spirit, and doth force his way
Through greatest dangers frightful to those eyes,
That wait to intercept him: Maria?
How like to Cynthia in her silver Orb
She seems to me, attended by loves Lamp
Whose mutual influence, and souls sympathy
Doth show, heavens model in mortality.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Gerardine?
Aurora now the blushing Sons approach,
Thou art not more comfort to this Universe
Than thou to me: most acceptably come,
The Art of number cannot count the hours
Thou hast been absent.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Infinity of Love
Holds no proportion with Arithmetic.
Think not Maria but my heart retains
A deep impression of such thoughts as these:
I have been forging of a mirthful Plot,
To celebrate our wished Conjunction;
Which now digested, come to summon thee
To be an Actress in the Comedy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: How, where, when, speak? mine ears are quick to hear, I stand on thorns already to be there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: At Dryfats house the Merchant, there is our Scene, Whose sequel (if I fail not in intent,) Shall answer our desires, and each content: But when sawest thou Lipsalue and Gudgeon our two gallants?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: They are here in the house: so handled by mine uncle, that they are the pitifullest patients that ever you beheld.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No matter, he serves them in their kind, they were infamous in the Court and now are grown as notorious in the City: they may happily prove particles in our sport, and fit subjects for laughter: Time calls me hence, adieu, prepare to meet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I shall outstrip the nimblest in my feet.

div2.stage:
Act.5. Scana vltima.
Enter Dryfat and Club.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Come Club come, there is a merry Fray towards, we shall see the death of melancholy, wherein thou and I must call a grand Jury of jests together, and pass upon them with the Club Law.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Now as I am O, the Crier, and yet but a young Club, I have not yet practiced that Law, you have a whole dryfat on it, I pray you instruct me?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Why it is a Law enacted (by the common counsel of Statute Caps) to qualify the rage of the Time, to follow, to call back, and sometimes to encounter gentlemen when they run in arrearages, I tell thee there is no averment against our Book Cases: It is the Law called make peace, it makes them even, when they are at odds, it shows them a flat case, as plain as a pack staff, that is, knocks them down without circumstance

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Aye marry I like that law well, it is studied with the turning of a hand: there is no quiddits, nor peddlers French in it, there needs no book for the exposition of the terms; it is as easily learned as the felling of wood, and getting of Children, all is but laying on load the down right blow.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aye and by the way of exhortation it prints this moral Sentence on their Costards, in Capital Letters Agree? for the Law is costly.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Good good; but all this while there is no Doctor thought on, we must have one to arbitrate;

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Why (master Gerardine ) man, has his name for the purpose, he shall be called Doctor Stickler, Lupus est in Fabula, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How now lads does our Conceit cotton, have you summoned your wits from woolgathering? Are you fraught with matter for this merriment?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Full full, we are in labour man, and we shall die without midwifery.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: We are ravished with delight like the wench that was got with child against her stomach --- O but if we could wrest this smock law (now in hand) to our Club law, it were excellent.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Easily, easily, all shall be called the Club law.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Why thus: Club is the Crier, I am Poppin the Proctor and you Stickler the Doctor, he calls them to appear, I must be of their counsel, and you must atone them put them together we may know their cases, and be in their Elements (mark you me) but they cannot be in ours, Tut, none knows our secrets, we can speak fustian above their understanding, and make Asses ears attentive, I will play Ambodexter tell them it is a plain Case and put them down with the club law; so that (as Club said well enough) our knavery is as near allied, as felling of wood and getting of children.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Excellent excellent, by this they are at hand; let us bear these things like ourselves; I will withdraw and put on my habiliments and then enter for the Doctor.

div2.stage:
Exit.
Enter Doctor Glister and Purge.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Do so, they come, they come? welcome Master Doctor Glister and master Purge, there is a commission to be sat upon this day, to open a passage for imprisoned truth, concerning Acts yet in tenebris.

sp.speaker: Do. Gl.
sp.p: True; I am brought hither by the malice of my wife

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: And I have a just Appeal against my wife.

sp.speaker: D. Gli.
sp.p: Master Exigent (so I think you are called) I understand you have the Law at your fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: I can box Cases, and scold and scratch it out amongst them

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Indeed fame reports you to be a good Trumpeter of causes, I must retain you sir to sound mine?

sp.speaker: Dryfat.
sp.p: My Sackbut shall do it most pathetically; tell me in brief the nature of your Case?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Faith sir, a scandalous Letter devised to wrong my reputation, about a Bastard in the Country which should be mine.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: About a Bastard in the Country which should be yours? hum; it is very like you then, it should seem.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O no sir, understand me, only fathered upon me.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Only fathered upon you, cum nemini obtrudi potest; I understand you and like you well too, you do not flatter yourself in your own Case, no: it is not good, well what more?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: And about my Niece got with child, in my own house.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Byrlady burthens of some weight, which you make light of --- you deny?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What else sir, I have reason.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I know it well, I take you for no beast: believe me (master Doctor) deny all and reason are two maine grounds, stand upon them and you cannot err. Your case master Purge?

sp.speaker: Purg
sp.p: First take your fee master Exigent, that you may have the more feeling, and urge it home when you come to it, mine is a discovery of my wives Iniquity at the Family of love.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Otherwise called the house of Venery, where they hunger and thirst for it.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: True sir, you have heard of the hole in the wall, where they assemble together in the day time, like so many Bees under a hive.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Come home Crura Thimo plena, and lodge among hornets, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I cannot tell sir, but for my part, I am much noted as I go

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: No doubt of that sir, your wife can furnish you with notes out of her Cotations.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Aye and give him a two tagged point to tie them together.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: But how came you to detect her?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Why thus sir: getting the word, I dogged her to the Family where closing with her I whispered so pleasing a tale in her ear, that I got from her her wedding Ring, and here it is.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Well, out of that ring we will wring matter that shall carry meat in the mouth. But what witness or proof can you produce to make good your wives iniquity, and your own Cuckoldry

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Master Lipsalue, and Master Gudgeon, who were her companions at that same time.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Very good are they cited in the quorum nomina?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: they will be here sir.

sp.speaker: D. Gli.
sp.p: If they be they will bewray all.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: So much the better it will savour well for Master Purge.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: You understand my case now?

sp.speaker: D. Gl.
sp.p: And mine too sir?

sp.speaker: Dri,
sp.p: I do I do, they are as different as a Doctor and a Dunce, a man and a beast, here is the compendium; yours master Doctor stands upon the negative, and yours master Purge upon the affirmative Pauca sapienti, I have it, I have it.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Mine is very currant sir, I can show you good gilt,

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aye marry, there spoke an Angel, guilt is currant indeed, let me feel it let me feel

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I mean my wives guilt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Master Poppin, you shall have Innocence to speak for me?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Tut, Innocence is a fool, I care not for his company, I can speak enough without him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then I hope you will be as good to us, as the five-finger at Maw.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: No rather as Hercules, to lip labour them with the Club Law, tut let me alone.

div2.stage: Enter Mistress Glister, Mistress Purge, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mi. Glist.
sp.p: O are you here sir, I have brought you a full barn to glut your greedy appetite if you have any maw, feed here till you choke again: Now shall I see the whole Carcass of your knavery ripped up, if thou hast any grace, now will thy red beard turn white upon it.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.l: O how have I been tossed from post to pillar,
In this libidinous world: the yoke I bear
Is so uneven, as if an Innocent Lamb
And a mad harebrained Ox should draw together:
But I must have patience there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: There is some difference between these two tempers.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I would give a hundred pounds my wife had so gentle a spirit.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: My wife must needs be gentle, for she can bear double.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Here comes master Doctor, now rig up your vessels, everyone to his Tackling.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good day to all at once, and peace amongst you: fie how I sweat, I think Vulcan never toiled so at his Anvil, as I have done, and all to make maids water to slake Cupids fire, and to turn his shafts from the featherbed to the bed post, from the heart to the heel: Come master Poppin shall we to this gear?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Reverend Doctor we have staid your coming: Crier cry silence?

Master Doctor: I have heard in general terms, the
Tales of master Doctor Glister, and master Purge, which have in mutual manner jumped into the Quagmire of my mind, out of which quagmire (by your enforcement, and mine own duty) I pluck them up by the ears, and thus in naked appearance I present them.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Adrem, adrem master Poppin: leave your allegories, your metaphors, and Circumlocutions, and to the point?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Then briefly thus: I have compared their tales, how short they will come of their wives I know not: and first for mistress Purge, Crier call mistress Purge?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Rebecca Purge, wife to Peter Purge apothecary, appear upon thy purgation, upon pain of excommunication.

sp.speaker: Mi.Pu.
sp.l: Here I am O times impiety!
Hither I come from out the harmless fold,
To have my good name eaten up by wolves:
See how they grin? well, the weak must to the wall,
I must bear wrong, but shame shall them befall.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Who is her accuser?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Her own husband upon the late discovery of a Crewe of narrow Rust straight laced, yet loose bodied Dames, with a Route of Omnium gatherums, assembled by the title of the family of love; which master Doctor if they be not punished and suppressed by our Club Law, each man's copy hold, will become free hold, specialities will turn to generalities and so from unity to parity, from parity to plurality, and from plurality to universality, their wives, the only ornaments of their houses and of all their wares, goods and Chattel, the chief movables will be made common.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Most Voluble and eloquent proctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Byrlady these Enormities must and shall be redressed, otherwise I see their Charter will be infringed, and their ancient Staff of government the Club (from whence we derive our law of Castigation) this club I say (they seeming nothing less than men by their forepart) will be turned upon their own heads. Speak Rebecca Purge art thou one of this family? hast thou ever known the body of any man there, or elsewhere Concupiscentically?

sp.speaker: Mi. P.
sp.p: No Master. Doctor, those are but devises of the wicked to trap the Innocent, but I thank my spirit I have fear before my eyes, which my husband sees not, because something hangs in his light.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: That is my horns: she flouts me to my face, and I will not endure it. I shall carry her mark to my grave: master Doctor she has given me that, that Esculapius (were he now extant) could not heal, nor Edax rerum take away?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Produce your witness Master. Purge, and blow out not your own horn?

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Master Lipsalue and master Gudgeon, let them be called.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Laurence Lipsalue and Gregory Gudgeon late of hic and vbiq, in the County of nusquam Gentlemen, come into the Court, and give your evidence, upon pain of that which shall ensue.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Here they come, in pain I warrant them: how works your physic Gallants? do you go well to the ground? now Cuckold the Doctor? wife who is your first man now, now strike with the scabbard: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: A villainous Doctor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Mountebank you are a rascal, and we will cast about to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Cast about this way, and bewray what you can concerning Mistress Purge, who stands here upon her purgation, either to prove mundified or contaminated, according to the tenor piece of your principal Evidence, first give them the Book?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Come, lay your hands upon the Book: you shall speak and aver no more, nor wade no farther into the Cream pots of this woman's crime, than the naked truth, and the cart-rope of your conscience shall conduct you, so help you the contents: kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.p:
Alas, we are not in case to answer largely, but if you will have our evidence in brief, I think I kissed her at the Family
some three times; once at coming, once at going, and once in the middest, otherwise never knew her dishonestly.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Aye, mark that middle kiss master Doctor?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: And for my part I have been more mortified by her, than ever I was provoked.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How say you to this master Purge, your witness is weak, and sir-reverence on, without sounder proof, they may depart to the close stool whence they came, and you to your Apothecaries shop.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: No master Doctor, I have an other bolt to shoot, that shall strike her dead, she shall not have a word to say.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Answer me to this Mistress Purge, where is your wedding Ring?

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: My wedding Ring? why what should I do with unnecessary things about me, when the poor begs at my gate ready to starve; is it not better (as I learned last Lecture) to send my substance before me, where I may find it, than to leave it behind me, where I must forgo it? yes verily; wherefore (to put you out of doubt) I have given that Ring to charitable uses?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Nay now she falters: my Client can show that Ring, got from her at the Family, when these two Courtling had at the same time beleaguered her Fort.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: This alters the Case clean, what starting hole have you now mistress Purge?

sp.speaker: Mi. Purge.
sp.p: Even the Sanctuary of a safe conscience: now truly, truly, (how ever he came by that Ring) by my Sisterhood I gave it to the relief of the distressed Geneua.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p:
How! to the relief of the distressed Geneua? Justice master Doctor: I may now decline victus victa victum, one word more shall overthrow her: I myself was a Familist that day, who more Jealous than zealous in devotion, thrust in amongst the rest (as I had most right) on purpose to sound her, to find out the knavery: short tale to make, I got her Ring, and here it is? let her deny it if she can; and
what more I discovered, non est nunc narrandi locus.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: Husband, I see you are hoodwinked in the right use of feeling and knowledge, as if I knew you not then, as well as the Child knows his own father, look in the posy of my Ringe: does it not tell you that we two are one flesh? and hath not fellow feeling taught us to know one another as well by night as by day? husband husband, will you do as the blind Jade, break your neck down a hill because you see it not? have you no light of nature in that flesh of yours? Now (as true as I live master Doctor I had a secret operation, and I knew him then to be my husband even by very instinct.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Impudence dost not blush? art not ashamed to lie so abominable.

sp.speaker: Mi. Pur.
sp.p: No husband, rather be you ashamed of your own weakness, for, for my part I neither fear nor shame what man can do unto me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Master Purge I see you have spent your pith; therefore best make a full point at the ring, and attend our pleasure, master Exigent proceed to the rest?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Crier, call Doctor Glister?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Doctor Glister, alias suppository doctor of physic, appear upon thy purgation, upon the belly pain that may ensue therein.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Who is his accuser?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: His clamorous wife, who seems to enforce a separation about a Bastard in the Country, which should be his, only fathered upon him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What proof of that?

sp.speaker: Mist. Gli.
sp.p: Proof unanswerable master Doctor, the Nurses Letter: let it be red, but first observe his countenance? it may be his blushing will bewray his guilt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Now by this light, I thought it had indeed, but I see it is but the reflection of his beard, Read the Letter Master Exigent?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
After my hearty commendations remembered unto
your worshipful doctorship, trusting in god that you are as well as I was at the making here of thanks be to him therefore, The cause of my writing unto you at this time is, to let you understand that your little son is turned a ragged colt, a very stripling, for being now stripped of all his clothing, his backside wants a tail-piece commends itself to your fatherly Consideration. Woe worth the time that ever I gave suck to a child that came in at the window, god knows how. Yet if you did but see how like the pert little read headed knave is, to his Father: and how like a Cock sparrow he mouses and touses my little Bess already, you would take him for your own, and pay me my hire, I write not of the want of one thing for I want all things, wherefore take some speedy order or else as naked as he came from the mother will I send him to the father. From Pis. the xxii of --- Your poor nurse Thomasiue Tweed es.

sp.speaker: Doctor:
sp.p: Master doctor: Truth needs not the foil of Rhetoric, I will only in Monesillaba answer for myself, (as sometimes a wise man did) such and such things are laid to my charge, which I deny, you may think of me what you please, but I am as innocent in this, as the child new born.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why there is partly a confession: the child we know is innocent and not new born neither: for it should seem by the letter he is able to call his dad, knave.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You take me wrong master Proctor?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p:
Under correction thus much can I say for my clients Justification; Indeed he hath travelled well in the beating of pulses, and hath been much conversant in women's Iordanes, but he had ever a care to raise his patient, being before cast down: his charitable disposition hath been such to poor folk, that he never took above four pence for the casting of a water, which good custom was so well known among all his patients, that if sixpence were at any time offered him they might be bold to ask and have two pence again. He hath been so skilful and painful withal, in the cure of the green sickness, that of my knowledge) he hath risen at all
hours in the night to pleasure maids that have had it. And for that foul mouthed disease termed by a fine phrase --- a pox on it what do you call it? O! the Grincomes, at that he hath played his doctors prize, and writes Nilvltra to all Bountibackes. So that the wise woman in Pissing alley, nor she in Do-little lane are more famous for good deeds than he. Then master Doctor, out of these presumptions, besides his flat denial (a more infallible ground) you may gather his innocence, and let him have his purgation.

sp.speaker: Gerardine.
sp.p: No Master Exigent it is not so to be foisted off.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gl.
sp.p: Nay master Doctor what say you to his own Niece that looks big upon him, an arrow that sticks for the upshot against all comers, which by his restraint of her, from master Gerardine an honest Gentleman that loved her, and upon that Colour from the sight and enter-course of other men, must by all presumptions be his own Act.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: O monstrous! this is a foul Blot in your Tables indeed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Wise thou hast no shame nor womanhood in thee, thy conscience knows me.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gli.
sp.p: True of thy flesh who knows not that? thy beard speaks for thee: Aye, Aye, thou liest by me like a Stone, but abroad thou art like a stone horse you old Timelister.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Cease your clamour, and attend my speech; most Worshipful, reverend and judicial Doctor, for the quickening of your memory I will give you a Breviate of all that hath been spoken: Master Doctor Glister hath a cradleful and a belly full (you see) thrust upon him, and master Purge a head fool. Your wife is an angry honey-less wasp, whose sting I hope you need not fear? and yours carries honey in her mouth, but her sting makes your forehead swell: your wife makes you deaf with the shrill treble of her tongue, and yours makes you horn mad with the tenor of her Tail. In fine, master Doctors refuge is his conscience, and Master Purge runs at his wives Ring.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Summa totalis, a good Audit, have you made master Exigent: now attend my Arbitrament: For you Gallants though you have incurred the danger of the Law, by using counterfeit keys, and putting your hands into the wrong pocket; yet because I see you punished and purged already, my advise is, that you learn the A.B.C. of better manners, go back and tell how you have ben used in the City, and being thus scoured keep yourselves clean, and the bed undefiled. For you Master Purge, because I see your Evidence insufficient, and indeed too weak to foil your wives uprightness, and seeing Jealousy and unkindness, hath only made her a stranger in your land of Ham; my counsel is that you readvance your Standard, give her new press money?

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: You may enjoin me sir but ---

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But not at me man, I will enjoin you, and conjoin you, and briefly thus, you have your Ring that has made this combustion and uproar, that keep still, wear it, and here by my edict be it proclaimed, to all that are jealous, to wear their wives Ring still on their fingers, as best for their security, and the only charm against Cuckoldry.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Then wise at master Doctors enjoinment (so thou wilt promise me to come no more at the Family) I receive thee into the lists of my favour.

sp.speaker: Mistr. Purge.
sp.p: Truly Husband my love must be free still to Gods creatures, yea nevertheless preserving you still as the head of my body, I will do as the Spirit shall enable me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Go to: thou hast a good wife, and there an end: upon you master Doctor (being solicited by so apparent proof) I can do no less than pronounce a severe sentence: and yet i'faith the reverence of your calling and profession doth somewhat check my austerity, what if master Gerardine (by my persuasion) would yet be induced to take your Niece and father the child, would you launch with a thousand pound, besides her fathers portion?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Master Doctor I would, were it but to redeem her lost good name.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then foreknowing what would happen, I thought good in master Gerardines name, to have this bond ready, which if you seal to, he shall take her with all faults.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That will I instantly --- So, this is done, which together with my Niece do I deliver by these presents to the use of master Gerardine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He thanks you heartily, and lets you know

sp.l: That Indian mines and Tagus glistering oar
To this bequest were unto me but poor.

sp.speaker: Doct. Gli.
sp.p: What! Gerardine, Dryfat and Club?

sp.speaker: Dry., Club.
sp.p: The very same: your are welcome to our Club Law?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Cease admiration here! what doubt remains
I will satisfy at full, now join with me,
For approbation of our Family.

sp.speaker: EPILOGVS.
sp.l: Gentles whose favour have over spread this place,
And shed the real influence of grace
On harmless mirth, we thank you, for our hope
Attracts such vigour and unmeasured scope
From the reflecting splendour of your eyes,
That grace presumed, fear in oblivion dies.
Your judgment as it is the Touch and Trier
Of good from bad, so from your hearts comes fire.
That gives both ardour to the wit refined,
And sweetness the Incense of each willing mind:
O may that fire never die, nor let your savours
Depart from us: give countenance to their labours
Proposed a Sacrifice, which may no less
Their strong desires, than our true zeals express.
